brewersTip.text: Sea buckthorn characteristics can vary from its country or origin. Taste the berries before addition to determine the best usage.

description.text: Vote Sepp is a single hop wheat beer brewed to a session strength, with hibiscus flower, which gives it an impressively vibrant shade of pink. What Vote Sepp lacks in complexity, it more than makes up for in a perfect balance of tartness, bitterness and body.

pairings: Caprese salad (mozzarella, tomato, basil, black pepper and sea salt)

brewersTip.text: Load hibiscus in the hot wort in a tea bag.

recipes.name: MAGIC STONE DOG
tags: SESSION FARMHOUSE IPA  STONE / MAGIC ROCK COLLAB

description.text: A session IPA brewed with a diverse grain bill, hopped with Simcoe and Amarillo and fermented with saison yeast, for an incredible level of depth in a low ABV beer. Spicy, fruity, complex, refreshing and dry.

brewersTip.text: Start the fermentation off at 20 C  and allow it to rise as high as 25 C . This will increase the fruity character of the yeast.

description.text: Russian Doll was an experimental set of brews showcasing the effects of varying the amount and ratio of malts in the grist. The barley wine had rich, chewy dark fruit aromas balanced with a spike of zesty hops. Toffee, apricot jam and grapefruit pith, crammed into the head of our little Russian Doll family.

brewersTip.text: Age the beer in bottle for a few months at cellar temperature to allow the hot alcohol characteristic to diminish.

description.text: Brewed for the opening of our first bar in Italy, BrewDog Firenze. A mega-hoppy Imperial Pilsner, with toasty malt complexity and tropical New World hops.

brewersTip.text: Sit this beer aside for a month to allow it to mellow.

recipes.name: U-BOAT
tags: SMOKED PORTER COLLAB WITH VICTORY BREWING

description.text: On the palate is a big dark malt sweetness, balanced by the blend of spicy Mittelfruh and citrussy Galena. Cocoa powder, rich dark chocolate, and ripe berries interplay with a toasty burnt sugar bitterness. The mouthfeel is thick and chewy with a treacly quality that doesnt cloy, as it plays off against the hops and roast malt bitterness.

brewersTip.text: A good Porter is dependant on a long fermentation and cellaring process. Keep the temperature controlled as much as possible.

twists.name: Try ageing on oak chips, infusing with rum raisins, or vanilla pods

description.text: A luscious blend of peach, blood orange and banana to make a suitably refreshing beverage that happily straddles the Atlantic.

pairings: Fish corn tacos with pomegranate salsa

brewersTip.text: Using a starter to get your yeast as vibrant and healthy as possible will make all the difference here.

description.text: A collaboration by BrewDog and CAP with Cascara green unroasted cherry coffee beans.

pairings: Pepper jack cheese burger on a brioche bun

brewersTip.text: Split the Cascara evenly between the mash and end of boil to really get the most out of it.

description.text: The levels of hops vary throughout the range. We love hops, so all four beers are big, bitter badasses, but by tweaking the amount of each hop used later in the boil and during dry- hopping, we can balance the malty backbone with some unexpected flavours. Simcoe is used in the whirlpool for all four beers, and yet still lends different characters to each.

pairings: Pork chops with spicy orange marmalade

brewersTip.text: Create balance through experimentation with the hop amounts and malt backbone.

description.text: The levels of hops vary throughout the range. We love hops, so all four beers are big, bitter badasses, but by tweaking the amount of each hop used later in the boil and during dry- hopping, we can balance the malty backbone with some unexpected flavours. Simcoe is used in the whirlpool for all four beers, and yet still lends different characters to each.

pairings: Lemon pound cake with a ice sugar glaze

brewersTip.text: Create balance through experimentation with the hop amounts and malt backbone.

description.text: The levels of hops vary throughout the range. We love hops, so all four beers are big, bitter badasses, but by tweaking the amount of each hop used later in the boil and during dry- hopping, we can balance the malty backbone with some unexpected flavours. Simcoe is used in the whirlpool for all four beers, and yet still lends different characters to each.

pairings: Roast chicken with vegetables and wild rice
Fresh pico de gallo with corn tortillas

brewersTip.text: Create balance through experimentation with the hop amounts and malt backbone.

description.text: Brewed with 100% malt, ten times the hops of most industrial lagers and cold-conditioned for five weeks, this spicy, robust Pilsner is lager reborn. Expect a robust, full-bodied malt character on the front of the tongue, spicy citrus notes as it goes back through the palate and an assertive bitter finish with a lemon and pepper character to round things off.

brewersTip.text: The most important thing about making a lager? Fermentation temperature! Do everything you can to control the ambient temperature to 9 - 12°C. In the old days, they used to brew lager over winter, so the colder temperature gave a much preferable fermentation profile. Ferment too hot and you beer will taste like yeasty bread.

description.text: BrewDog vs. Weihenstephan India Pale Weizen kicked off a new direction for our collaborations. We took a simple concept (by our standards) and teamed up with the oldest brewery in the world to brew a mash-up beer using the signature styles of both breweries. India Pale Weizen has classic base hefeweizen aromas and flavours of banana, clove and bubblegum, with a distinctive haziness. Layered on top of this is a tapestry of US citrus hop character. India Pale Weizen is a perfect symbiosis of traditional and modern brewing.

pairings: Waffles with caramelised apple and powdered sugar

brewersTip.text: Let the fermentation temperature creep up a couple of degrees higher than normal to create the characteristic banana and bubblegum aromas.

description.text: A triple whammy of coffee from HasBean gives our 17th Abstrakt concept beer an intense and roasty, dark mocha character. We brewed with espresso in the mash, cafetiere in the boil, and whole roast beans in the whirlpool and the fermenter.

brewersTip.text: Use freshly ground coffee for the best aromatic hit.

description.text: Named in a slight deviation from our Hello My Name Is series, Konnichiwa Kitsune is a Japanese- inspired, yuzu-infused Imperial IPA, brewed with Amarillo, Cascade and Citra. These punchy new world hops bring orange, grapefruit and lime to back up the yuzu aroma and flavour. Big mandarin notes, balanced against a caramel malt biscuity base.

pairings: Fresh seared tuna and rocket salad

brewersTip.text: Squeeze the fresh yuzu juice directly into the beer after primary fermentation is complete. Putting it in the hot wort may seem like better practice, but the juice will cook and some of the fresh citrus character will be lost.

description.text: Prototype Challenge 2014. All Day Long is a mild like no other. This complex, low-alcohol brew was the third of our 2014 Prototypes. Featuring a boatload of seven different speciality malts and some of our favourite hops, this beer is resinous at first, transitioning into something akin to bitter orange marmalade spread onto a thick bread crust. This is for everyone who said BrewDog would never brew a mild

pairings: Prawn toast with sweet chilli sauce

brewersTip.text: In any low ABV fermentation after primary fermentation has finished if the beer smells or tastes like wort, allow it to condition on the yeast for an extra 24 - 48 hours. This can round the profile off well.

description.text: Hop Fiction is an explosively tropical US-style Pale Ale. We rolled up our hop-dusted sleeves and put some advanced brewing techniques to work on this seasonal brew. Hop Fictions incredible aromas and flavours are down to a combination of early and late hops. Bags of soft, rounded citrus and stone fruit layer up on a dry light biscuit backbone. Hop Fiction, beer fact.

brewersTip.text: Don't be scared by the amount of hops. Seriously this beer can handle them.

description.text: A foundation of caramel malt is buttressed by a raucously resinous bitterness, as the rioting backdrop of citrus and tropical fruit flow in waves from those twin titans of the US  Centennial and Amarillo. And it also happens to be gluten free.

brewersTip.text: Add .75g (0.026oz) of Brewers Clarex to your fermentation vessel during casting.

description.text: This is the Vietnamese Coffee Edition. At 12.7% ABV, Black Eyed King Imp is a super intense and twistedly complex brew, with intense notes of sweet vanilla, rich espresso, smooth molasses and bitter chocolate barely contained by the container it's in.

brewersTip.text: Buying top notch coffee beans make a huge difference here.  Give them a very course grind to get the most out of them

description.text: Brewed with our Equity Punks this rich, smooth stout is brewed with a blend of six malts, resulting in a welcoming, resonant black beer. From start to finish it carries an intense roastiness reminiscent of dark chocolate intertwined with a delicate hint of coconut and caramel.

pairings: Butternut squash soup with toasted almonds

brewersTip.text: Lightly toast the coconut chips to allow better interaction with the hot wort.

recipes.name: RESTORATIVE BEVERAGE FOR
tags: AN EXTRACT TAKEN FROM "A TREATISE ON FOOD AND DIET"

description.text: Brewed to 8.5%, light as a mass market Pilsner in colour, fermented to be as dry as a Lambic, but as bitter as any double IPA and loaded with as much hop aroma as we can get into a beer. The fermentables in this beer were Marris Otter Extra Pale along with plenty of sugar as we mashed at a very low temperature to ensure maximum fermentability and attenuation. This beer is fermented within an inch of its life making it dry, sheer and bright. Citra, Amarillo & Centennial were all used in abundance in the kettle and also fired extremely liberally at this beer with our high tech hop cannon.

pairings: Habanero spicy chicken wings with ranch sauce

brewersTip.text: Allow the mash to sit at lower temperatures for an extended period to convert the maximum amount of starch to fermetable sugars. This will give the beer a higher ABV and dry it out.

description.text: Roasty, dark and complex, Stereo Wolf is a 5.2% ABV Stout brewed with a cacophony of hop-driven fruit and spice. Dark chocolate stalks alongside the resonating bitterness, through to Stereo Wolfs lingering dry finish. Balancing roasty malt and new world hops at 5.2% ABV is no mean feat, but Stereo Wolf takes it in its stride.

brewersTip.text: Special W is a specialty malt that creates an intense profile of nuts, raisins and caramel. It provides a focal point for the malt base, that the hops can stack against.

description.text: A Pilot Brew "Sunshine on Rye" uses loads of spicy malt and coriander to play nice with an inhuman amount of hops!

brewersTip.text: Indian coriander accentuates the citrus character from the hops.  Use fresh spices to really accentuate this relationship.

description.text: Ice-distilled double barley wine brewed by Chris from Stone Brewing Co. (see Sunmaid Stout) and BrewDog's own brewers.  As robust, resinous and badass as its eponymic beard.

brewersTip.text: Ferment first with the American ale strain and after a week add the American Ale II to really push up the ABV. Use a starter to get the yeast raring  and ready to go before the second addition.

twists.name: Ice-distilled after fermentation to get to 18.3%

recipes.name: HELLO MY NAME IS LITTLE INGRID

description.text: This beer hits all the high-points of Hello My Name is Ingrid  with one important exception. Brewed at 4.4% abv, Little Ingrid is a session- strength version of our cloudberry- infused celebration of all that is epic about Sweden. The zesty balance of citrus from the four different hops is just as pronounced as in the original.

pairings: Oysters with a chilli and dill sauce

brewersTip.text: Sourcing fresh cloudberries might involve a trip to Sweden but boy are they worth it.

description.text: 2015 IPA is Dead series. Often used as a combination hop for American Pale Ales and IPAs, Chinook can really shine when left to front a beer all on its own. The main reason for this is that its thunderously piney, with a fistful of spice kicked up in your face as you lie on the beach. A true heavyweight of the brewing industry.

pairings: Chicken fajita spiced monteray jack quesadillas
Chilli lime and coriander marinated king prawn cocktail

brewersTip.text: Chinook is a hop that can really shine on its own so don't be shy and really throw it at this IPA

description.text: 2015 IPA is Dead Series. Supremely floral, this hugely under-rated hop is related to Galaxy and was first cultivated in the Australian state of Victoria. Initially given the same name as a certain Eurolager, their lawyers got involved and the St- prefix was dropped. Ella displays subtle notes of spice, but is fundamentally a truly floral bouquet, redolent of the Southern Hemisphere.

pairings: Cheddar cheese toastie on dark rye
Lamb samosas with chilli dipping sauce

brewersTip.text: These beers need to hit FG to really pop. If you're fermentation is struggling, whip up a starter and re-pitch to get some viable yeast in there to finish the job

description.text: From the central European plains of Germany, comes something very different. A blast of tangerine and orange, Mandarina Bavaria brings a highly distinctive backbone of flavour. This is down to its parent  Cascade  and a frankly enormous 70% myrcene oil content. If equate Germany solely with earthy, spicy Noble hops, Mandarina Bavaria will make you think again.

brewersTip.text: We've mentioned the importance of fresh hops previously but this one really demands that your hops are the absolute freshest.

description.text: 2015 IPA is Dead Series. Pioneer hails from the hop gardens of Kent, and for those expecting something classically English, they surprise with an unforeseen blast of lemony citrus. Bookended with a herbal, cedar quality, these high alpha UK hops pack a pithy zing not often seen from these hop-growing isles.

brewersTip.text: Ensure to get the dry hops in and out within 3 days to ensure you capture the best of the hop.

description.text: Savagely bitter, exceptionally dry, this IPA is born to die on a predetermined day. It proudly displays its short-lived life span front and centre. There is no better time to drink this than the moment you get your paws on it. Awesome bitterness backed up by unrelenting aromas of resin, citrus, and juicy fruit. Born To Die is a eulogy to the hops that sacrificed themselves in its creation. An incredibly ambitious and satisfying small batch brew.

pairings: Caramelised onion and lightly seared steak

brewersTip.text: Fresh is best with this beer. Use fresh hops in the brew and during dry hop stages. Condition just long enough to let the powerful grassy aroma cut back - and drink.

description.text: A Pilot Brew with 200Kg of fresh melon and 5Kg fresh cucumber added after fermentation to produce the perfect summer refreshment.

brewersTip.text: Have a good food proccesser to blend up all the melon and cucumber, also sieve out the seeds from the melon.

description.text: Pilot Brew: A twist on an English Bitter style beer, using Sorachi Ace hops throughout making a showcase of the off the dill and lemon character.

brewersTip.text: The touch of rye adds a great touch of spice that plays off the hops really well.

twists.name: This beer was unfiltered to give it a traditional ale appearance

description.text: Pilot Brew - Truffle & Chocolate Stout. Deep, earthy roast notes make this a gastronome's dream.

brewersTip.text: A little truffle goes a long way.  Add 5g, leave for a 2 days and add more if needed.

description.text: Hoppy citrus and tropical fruit Saison.

brewersTip.text: The stepped mash really makes the most out the raw ingredients.  If you can't achieve this mash for 60mins at 65°C.

description.text: Deconstructed whisky sour, reconstructed as a beer.

hops.name: Amarillo Citra Simcoe
hops.when: Dry Hop Dry Hop Dry Hop

brewersTip.text: Get the pH as low as possible with the kettle sour, pH of 3.2-3.5 is best.

description.text: Think bakewell tart with Christmas spices.

pairings: Wild rice salad with wild mushrooms

brewersTip.text: In the boil: cinnamon, star anise, clove, guinea pepper. After fermentation add: raspberry puree, cherry concentrate, bitter almond extract, American oak chips and Tahitian vanilla beans.

description.text: A keg-only Summer special, hop- bursted and dry-hopped to infinity.

brewersTip.text: Make sure the dry hops get plenty of contact with the beer! Weigh them down in a muslin sack if using whole leaf.

twists.name: Most of the hops are added in the whirlpool and dry hop stages

description.text: Democratically voted on by you and the BrewDog beer community. A wonderfully burnt toast malt backbone, loaded with American Hops for floral, citrus flavours and warm boozy vanilla and toasted oak.

brewersTip.text: Steep the oak chips and vanilla in separate bags in the cold conditioning phase. Taste every 2 - 3 days and as soon as profile is desirable they can be removed easily.

description.text: Dog D is an extra special brew, marking 8 years of BrewDog. Like Dog A, B & C before it, Dog D is an Imperial Stout with speciality ingredients, only this time weve barrel-aged it too. Dog D pours like dark matter into your glass, with a deep tan head. The nose is subtle but powerful, and on the palate, theres a treacle toffee backbone, supporting the spicy hop flavour and naga chilli heat.

brewersTip.text: Steep the coffee in the hot wort for short periods to get the best extraction of aromatic oils, without gaining too much bitterness.

twists.name: Add 1 naga chilli in the FV

description.text: Hinterland is a beer long in the creation, and even longer in the appreciation. On the aroma, deep reverberating roasty bitterness and sweet dark chocolate. Also in evidence, woodsmoke, rich vanilla, mocha and marzipan. When tasting, Hinterland reveals itself as the beer moves from cellar temperature to something warmer, yielding all of the above plus dried fruit, rich ganache and ending on a resoundingly warming finish redolent of chocolate liqueur or plum brandy.

pairings: Venison with warm spices (cardamom) and sweet potato

brewersTip.text: Towards the end of the fermentation allow the temperature to free rise. This will let the yeast finish off the fermentation and scour off-flavours from the beer.

description.text: 9% ABV sour tripel, infused with peach and apricot in collaboration with some of our favourite beer writers Adrian Tierney-Jones, Matt Curtis and Jonny and Brad from The Craft Beer Channel.

brewersTip.text: 20% of the original volume of wort was brewed again, kettle soured and added during fermentation to give a tart finish to the beer.

recipes.name: HELLO MY NAME IS HOLY MOOSE

description.text: Cloudberry, lingonberry, blueberry and sea buckthorn meld with citrusy hops in an intensely sweet, fruity and floral aroma, with toasty malt notes and tropical fruit bursts. This bitter, resinous IPA follows up with a lemony punch in the mouth - cherry and blueberry sourness takes this pithy pale ale in a new direction before a long, dry finish.

brewersTip.text: The mixture of berries and hops create a very intense flavour profile, a great brew for using up some spare hops.

description.text: Wonderfully tart, bitter, piney and filled with the fruity elements from raspberries, blueberries and sour cherries. Oh, and its purple.

brewersTip.text: Try to find the ripest berries possible to impart as much juicy goodness as possible. These can be forzen until you have the full set.

description.text: Kettle soured hoppy mango gose. A delicate balance of sweet, juicy mango, sour lime and salinity.

brewersTip.text: Try to use the juiciest, ripest mangoes possible.

description.text: In this northern German style retro altbier, weve dialled down the dry-hops to zero, but cranked up the malt to create massive aromas. Toasty, toffee and floral notes duke it out for supremacy in the headspace of your glass. When this all hits your palate, the steely bitterness combines with the rich dry malt and the subtle alcohol warmth in a full throttle attack on your taste buds.

brewersTip.text: Make sure that the boil is vigorous enough to roll. This means that high flavours are active, and undesirable compounds like DMS are not left in the beer.

description.text: We're turning Halloween inside out and upside down. Pumpkin King is not your usual unctuous, cloyingly sweet Halloween pumpkin ale. Sure, theres a huge heady hit of pungent spice on the nose, but its followed with bright and zesty citrus flavours, and a light mouthfeel. Spicy and sweet autumnal favourites like toasted marshmallow and toffee apple are just some of the complex notes youll find in our twisted take on a pumpkin ale, which weighs in at 5.4% ABV.

pairings: Creamy maple syrup and bacon soup
Chunky chicken and vegetable spiced stew

brewersTip.text: Experiment with the spice addition to find the correct balance to suit your taste. FYI star anise is a very strong flavour.

description.text: A hark back to the origins of Saison; slight spice and earthy notes with highlights of lemon and pepper make a beer that could quench the thirst of any seasonal worker.

brewersTip.text: Ferment between 21 and 24°C to get this saison as dry as possible

description.text: A cunning cocktail blend of grapefruit hops, ginger spice and refreshing mint.

brewersTip.text: Use more freshly grated ginger in the mash to get a real spicy nature to the beer.

description.text: Orange blossom honey braggot. A floral easy drinker with a hint of citrus.

brewersTip.text: If possible use the orange blossom honey addition at the end of fermentation to carbonate the beer, this will keep the delicate blossom honery aroma from escaping.

description.text: Doodlebug is our fusion of low strength and enormously high tropical hop levels  think a mashup of Hop Fiction and How to Disappear Completely, and youre almost there. Clocking in at 2.8% ABV, Doodlebug is keg-only and is packed with Amarillo, Chinook and Mosaic; letting fly a hoppy buzzbomb at sub-session-strength.

pairings: Fried calamari with a mild sauce

brewersTip.text: Wheat and flaked oats can help to add to the body of the beer. This makes up for the lack of alcoholic bite.

description.text: No Label is a postmodern, postgender non-binary brew; the worlds first beer made with transgender hops. Brewed with whole hop bines that have spontaneously changed from female to male, no label goes its own way. No Label balances a light, biscuity dryness from the malt base with delicate hints of fruity esters gifted by the fermentation. Finally, dry- hopping adds a layer of new world tropical & pine flavours that add a unique twist to this classic Kölsch style beer. All profits from the sales of this beer were donated to LGBTQI+ events organisers Queerest of the Queer.

pairings: Strawberry and basil salad with feta

brewersTip.text: Dry hop using a muslin bag in order to give you the best chance at getting the signature Kölsch clarity.

description.text: Spiced peppercorn and rhubarb Saison.

brewersTip.text: Be prepared to give your Saison yeast plenty of time to do its thing. Its not unheard of for Saison fermentation taking 6-8 weeks.

description.text: BrewDogs level of dry-hop to a beer formed with a baseline of 100% pilsner malt  and at under 4.5% ABV  gives you a style that flirts at the edges of several others. Think aromas of fresh cut grass, nettle, white grape, melon, tangerine - with similar flavours leading to a dry, bitter finish.

brewersTip.text: Let the beer lager at a low temperature for 3-4 weeks before adding the dry hops.

description.text: Brown ales are perfect foils for resinous C-Hops, as the piney elements of the latter contrast brilliantly with the sweeter, nutty elements of the malt bill. The best of both worlds.

brewersTip.text: High carbonate water will really accent the malt notes to better balance the punchy hops.

description.text: This tentacled terminator packs a punch - ten punches to be precise. Each hop addition adds to the intense layers of depth in this red rye IPA. Toasty caramel & cinder toffee from crystal malts, cacao richness from intensely roasted malt and the spiciness of rye. Zesty pithiness from Citra and the robust resin of Chinook. This small batch exclusive brew is up-front intensity matched with twisted complexity. The can features awesome custom art from Joe Wilson.

pairings: Rocket and mozzarella salad with a cracked pepper dressing
Fried halibut with sweet potato fritters

brewersTip.text: 20% specialty malts in this grist can create problems in the run off. Be careful not to pull the bed down onto the plates.

description.text: Tart, dry and acidic with a punch of summer berry as rhubarb crumble.

malts.name: Propino Pale Malt for kettle souring Acidulated Malt for kettle souring

brewersTip.text: Fruits added at the end of the boil for 10 mins and additional added in maturation. Boil for no more than 15 mins.

twists.name: Raspberries in the boil, rhubarb at maturation. Soured naturally using the kettle souring technique

description.text: Running the knife-edge between an India Pale Ale and a Stout, this particular style is one we truly love. Black IPAs are a great showcase for the skill of our brew team, balancing so many complex and twisting flavours in the same moment. The citrus, mango and pine from the hops  three of our all-time favourites  play off against the roasty dryness from the malt bill at each and every turn.

pairings: Halibut with a mango and tomato salad

brewersTip.text: Be as accurate as possible when weighing out your malts to ensure you strike the right balance.

description.text: Punchy resinous hoppy aromas blast from the glass; light floral and citrus notes riff against huge piney character. Showcasing Citra, Simcoe and Amarillo at their absolute best. A huge dose of grapefruit peel brings swirls of fresh pithy zest, accentuating the dry hops and building on the dry, biscuit malt base.

pairings: Coriander and lime green thai curry

brewersTip.text: Shave of the surface of the citrus peel to unlock the highly aromatic compounds into the beer.  Avoid putting any white pith into the brew as it will create an intense and unpleasant bitterness.

twists.name: Add as much grapefruit and orange peel as you dare and FV for extra citrus twist

description.text: Japanese citrus fruit intensifies the sour nature of this German classic.

malts.name: Propino Pale Malt for kettle souring Acidulated Malt for kettle souring

brewersTip.text: Clean everything twice.  All you want is the clean sourness of lactobacillus.

twists.name: Soured naturally using the kettle souring technique

description.text: An experiment in balancing hops on the pilot kit. Grapefruit, orange and resin to the fore.

pairings: Penne with tomato and smoked cheese
Salted caramel ice cream and peanuts

brewersTip.text: Hold off on the dry hops. You want to know how well you balanced the brew house.

description.text: A cheeky play with a new hop on the pilot kit. Expect notes of redcurrant, melon and citrus. An intriguing possibility for the future.

pairings: Jalapeño poppers with blue cheese dip
Carrot cake with cream cheese frosting

brewersTip.text: Enigma has a very high alpha acid so be careful not to over do the bittering hops.

description.text: Good things come to those who wait. This smooth and roasty oatmeal milk stout won our 2015 Prototype Challenge at a canter. Roasty coffee and chocolate lead to a decadent, full-bodied richness of near uncharted depths with a velvet mouthfeel from the addition of oatmeal and a touch of wheat. This is complemented at every turn by the Magnum and Sorachi Ace hops, with the latter bringing an intensity of smooth vanilla and dark berry fruit on the long, rewarding finish.

brewersTip.text: There's a lot of speciality malt in the mash. Make sure you take the run off nice and steady  increase the flow too much and pull in the bed at your peril.

description.text: We love hops. We adore and worship their profile ability to transform beer. You could say that we have a terminal addiction. To celebrate this fetish were heroing our favourites in single hopped limited releases. No also starring, no extras, no compromise. The Hop is the Hero. A biscuity malty backbone builds to resinous pine with explosive citrus notes, culminating in a mango hit and a long bitter finish. This is pure Hop fusion, imploding with sensory overload. Our Ace in the hole, devastatingly singular, deliciously bitter. Serving up an Ace each and every time.

brewersTip.text: Try adding a small portion of the hops to the kettle before you boil, as first wort hops.

description.text: This mezcal-inspired brew is the shipwrecked remains of a collaboration brewed with former craft brewers Ballast Point. Brewed to encapsulate the flavours of mezcal, this beer smoulders with peaty and light woody notes, as well as intense fruity character.

brewersTip.text: Nail your colours to the mother fucking mast  independence or death.

twists.name: 100g Oak chips soaked in Mezcal and 1.6kg Agave syrup in FV

recipes.name: MONK HAMMER
tags: OUR RUTHLESS IPA WITH A BELGIAN TWIST

description.text: Jack Hammer has been single handedly ripping it up for quite some time. Now, the definitive bitter and twisted IPA, has spawned four Hammer Head off-springs. Monk Hammer is the first of our super-charge hyped up hybrids. A dark cloaked holy man packing an unholy punch. Belgian yeast and American hops untie on a cardinal scale. Steel yourself for biblical volumes of grapefruit, bow your head for a wave of spicy, fruity yeast character, then cross yourself for the bitterest of bitter finishes. Let your senses succumb to this 21 st century incarnation. Monk Hammer  worship daily.

brewersTip.text: Oxygen is critical for this strain of yeast so make sure you aerate your wort properly.

description.text: Our spin on a light, dry and bitter German lager. Hop driven with malt taking a back seat, Pils 2.0 is lined up to become a regular brew.

pairings: Tuna & salmon sushi (with plenty of wasabi!)

brewersTip.text: Allow plenty of time for lagering with this brew to make sure you get the clean and crisp flavour profile.

description.text: We are bringing back our Blitz Series to 2016. Every Blitz we brew is different, due to the spontaneous souring process, and each version has a great blend of all the different flavours we look for in a Berlinerwiesse.

pairings: French fries dressed in good oil and salt

brewersTip.text: When you have a good lactobacillus culture grown take half of an fv of it and add some fresh wort. This will keep the culture alive as long as you keep it warm, oxygen free and keep releasing the pressure. You can then use this liquid culture on the next brew and reuse it over and over and over and over and over...like sourdough starter!

description.text: Dog E is a very special beer. This beer commemorates our 9 th year in 2016. This beer originally appeared as AB:04 in 2010, perhaps the most sought after beer we ever brewed. Dog E is a 16.1% Imperial Stout brewed with copious amounts of dark malts, pure cacao and coffee, balanced by the subtle addition of naga chili, and barrel-aged. Perfect for ageing in your cellar, or drinking fresh if youre lucky enough to get your paws on a bottle.

brewersTip.text: With stronger styles (like imperial stouts), feel free to cellar your beer and try a bottle every few months to see how the flavours have developed  often the beer picks up new, incredible flavours.

twists.name: 5g Habanero and 3g lemon drop chili in FV

description.text: Hinterland is a beer long in the creation, and even longer in the appreciation. On the aroma, deep reverberating roasty bitterness and sweet dark chocolate. Also in evidence, woodsmoke, rich vanilla, mocha and marzipan. When tasting, Hinterland reveals itself as the beer moves from cellar temperature to something warmer, yielding all of the above plus dried fruit, rich ganache and ending on a resoundingly warming nish redolent of chocolate liqueur or plum brandy. Aged in Bourbon Casks.

pairings: Venison with warm spices (cardamom) and sweet potato

brewersTip.text: Towards the end of the fermentation allow the temperature to free rise. This will let the yeast finish off the fermentation and scour off-flavours from the beer.

description.text: An English Barley Wine brewed with coffee and milk, with rich toasty & caramel flavours. To complete the tiramisu effect, weve blended this with a 3 year rum cask aged Imperial Stout.

brewersTip.text: Use only very dry coffee beans like Sumatran ones. This way your head retention will not be affected by the oils from the beans.

recipes.name: BARREL AGED ALBINO SQUID ASSASSIN
tags: RED RYE IPA AGED IN RYE WHISKY CASK

description.text: This tentacled terminator packs a punch - ten punches to be precise. Each hop addition adds to the intense layers of depth in this red rye IPA. Toasty caramel & cinder toffee from crystal malts, cacao richness from intensely roasted malt and the spiciness of rye. Zesty pithiness from Citra and the robust resin of Chinook. This small batch exclusive brew is up-front intensity matched with twisted complexity. Aged in Rye Whisky Casks.

pairings: Rocket and mozzarella salad with a cracked pepper dressing
Fried halibut with sweet potato fritters

brewersTip.text: 20% specialty malts in this grist can create problems in the run off. Be careful not to pull the bed down onto the plates.

description.text: A 4.7% German Pils with light, biscuit and toasty malt character, upon which is built a hop bitterness that provides complexity and a long, dry finish.

brewersTip.text: Keep an eye on your fermentation temperature to ensure you get the crisp notes that are the hallmark of a good pilsner.

description.text: Intense peaty smoke layers on decadent roast coffee and chocolate in our Islay barrels aged paradox stout. One of the smokiest beers we have ever produced.

brewersTip.text: Get a whisky barrel to add the extra depth to your beer. Alternatively use oak chips or Whisky soaked wood.

description.text: We love hops. We adore and worship their profile ability to transform beer. You could say that we have a terminal addiction. To celebrate this fetish were heroing our favourites in single hopped limited releases. No also starring, no extras, no compromise. The Hop is the Hero. A biscuity malty backbone builds to intense resinous pine with pithy citrus notes, culminating in a grapefruit hit and a long bitter finish. Our Ace in the hole, devastatingly singular, deliciously bitter. Serving up an Ace each and every time.

brewersTip.text: Use whole leaf hops for the dry hopping. Theyre much easier to get out.

description.text: We gave our customers the keys to the brewery and let them choose every aspect of this beer. Sour cherry combines with fruity hop character against a biscuit malt backbone with a hint of alcohol warmth, and an oaky undercurrent.

brewersTip.text: Rope in as many friends as you can to make it a truly democratic brew.

description.text: The Overlord of mango and chili IPAs packs a fruity punch and then some. Pours a slightly hazy orange. A tropical fruit assault on the nose, with mango, pineapple, apricots and citrus. Hints of chili and sweet malts follow. Fruit dissipates to a chili kick, not hot but definitely there, followed by a long bitter finish. All hail to the hot tempered sweet toothed Lord.

brewersTip.text: This fermentation is going to be wild. Use a blow off rather than an airlock to cope with the extra activity.

recipes.name: BLACK HAMMER
tags: OUR RUTHLESS IPA WITH A DARK MALT TWIST

description.text: Jack Hammer has been single handedly ripping it up for quite some time. Now, the definitive bitter and twisted IPA, has spawned four Hammer Head off-springs. Black Hammer is the second of our hyped up hybrid IPAs. A black hearted beast, that takes no prisoners. American hops and dark malt combine to make mischief. Grapefruit and coffee collide in sensory overload  a wake-up call for other IPAs. Molten waves of pithy grapefruit build and finally ebb to the roasty bitter onslaught. Stand rm and wield the Black Hammer with care. Stare into the black abyss and succumb to the dark-side.

pairings: Buffalo wings with blue cheese dip

brewersTip.text: You may have to leave this beer on dry hops for slightly longer than usual to let the flavours balance.

description.text: We love hops. We adore and worship their profile ability to transform beer. You could say that we have a terminal addiction. To celebrate this fetish were heroing our favourites in single hopped limited releases. No also starring, no extras, no compromise. The Hop is the Hero. A biscuity malty backbone layered with berry and resin, culminating with a lime zest hit and an explosive bitter citrus finish. Our Ace in the hole, devastatingly singular, deliciously bitter. Serving up an Ace each and every time.

brewersTip.text: Let the wort sit for 30 minutes after flameout before cooling to get the most out of that last hop addition.

recipes.name: CHILI HAMMER
tags: OUR RUTHLESS IPA WITH A FIERY TWIST

description.text: Chili Hammer is the third of our super-charged hyped up hybrids. A smooth tongued spicy assassin. Chili and American hops unite for a flavour bigger than Texas. Citrus peel, mango, with a hint of spice on the nose. Delivers big grapefruit and mango with a smooth chili kick, followed by the bitterest of bitter finishes. Chili Hammer  turn up the gas.

brewersTip.text: There are a multitude of chilies you can experiment with. Try the difference between Arbol and Habaneros.

description.text: We love hops. We adore and worship their profile ability to transform beer. You could say that we have a terminal addiction. To celebrate this fetish were heroing our favourites in single hopped limited releases. No also starring, no extras, no compromise. The Hop is the Hero. A biscuity malty backbone builds to intense tropical fruit, with bitter resin notes, culminating with an explosive papya hit and a long bitter finish. Our Ace in the hole, devastatingly singular, deliciously bitter. Serving up an Ace each and every time.

brewersTip.text: If you are struggling with the malt hop balance, try upping the speciality malt a little bit until you hit your sweet spot.

recipes.name: RYE HAMMER
tags: OUR RUTHLESS IPA WITH A SPICY TWIST

description.text: Rye Hammer is the fourth of our super-charged hyped up hybrids. A bready beery beast. Rye grains and American hops unite in an agricultural superpower. Aroma of roasted malts, rye bread and subtle floral hops. Grapefruit, roasted caramel with malty fruity notes, followed by the bitterest of bitter finishes. Rye Hammer  liquid daily bread.

brewersTip.text: The amount of rye shouldnt cause a stuck mash, but if you find you are having problems the addition of rice hulls to your mash can help.

description.text: Loaded with roasty coffee notes and balanced with complex tobacco character. With smoky flavours from the malt, our Beavertown Collab is barrel-aged, but we dont know for how long until its ready!

pairings: Aged cheddar, chickpea & roasted vegetable tagine

brewersTip.text: Add your Dark Muscavado for the last ten minutes of the boil.

description.text: Our spin on one-of the most popular beer styles ever conceived. A celebration of light, bready malt, with toasty hints and soft bitterness.

pairings: Salt beef bagel with mustard & pickles

brewersTip.text: Lagering is key to traditional German styles. A Helles lives or dies on its light, bready & toasty malt flavours  give them months to develop (at cold temperatures) for an outstanding Helles.

description.text: A huge, chewy barley wine, loaded with bitterness and balanced with a sweet and spicy combo of mango and chili. A concept brew which was so well received, we tweaked it and it became Neon Overlord.

brewersTip.text: Crack open the chili and add it in a muslin bag so you can take it out when the chilli heat suits you.

description.text: A beer brewed specifically for the British Science Festival, held in Swansea.

brewersTip.text: This beer is all about the balance between the malty backbone of the beer and the fresh hop aroma. The fresher the hops the better.

description.text: Honey & Lemon Blitz sees tart Berliner Weisse character multiplied by lemony acidity; light bready malt and a hint of warming honey hold this back from the brink of palate- destroying sourness.

brewersTip.text: Be careful not to over do the smoked malt as its just a background flavour and you dont want it to be prominent in the finished beer.

mashTips: Following souring steps outlined in Blitz Series recipes

description.text: Belgium meets Berlin  incredible saison character with a bright and vibrant sour edge.

brewersTip.text: This will ferment out very dry due to the yeast.

mashTips: Following souring steps outlined in Blitz

description.text: We asked the public to tell us the one beer we should brew again, from our entire back catalogue. They chose well. Cloudberries team up with pan-global hops for an all out fruit riot against a caramel malt base.

brewersTip.text: Add the cloudberries to your beer when racking the beer after primary fermentation. Grind them into a paste to allow maximum flavour extraction.

description.text: Our crew designed it, and we bottled it just for ourselves! We chose an 8% red ale, mash hopped and first wort hopped with New Zealand origin hops.

brewersTip.text: Bring a few bottles to your local BrewDog bar when it's done and ask the staff if you got it right, they're the only ones who can tell you for sure! They'll also probably know of other homebrewers and beer enthusiasts nearby that you can link in with to share your experiences and get awesome first hand advice from.

description.text: Our Blitz series sees us brew up low abv, super tart Berliner Weisse, and generally infuse them with bags of sour fruit flavour  but this batch uses gin botanicals instead.

brewersTip.text: Crack open/mash up the Juniper berries to get the most flavour and aroma from them.

description.text: AB:21 is a liquorice and blackcurrant infused imperial stout. Rolling in at an imposing 12% abv, this huge and decadent dark beer dials down the charred roastiness and focuses instead on the rich, full-bodied chocolate and dark fruit character of the style.

brewersTip.text: As with all of our Abstrakts this one is great for ageing. Be extra vigilant at all times as a small fault now will lead to disaster a few years down the line.

description.text: We gave our Equity Punks the keys to the brewery and let them brew the beer, as well as join Q&As and tour our HQ. The beer was voted on exclusively by Equity Punks.

brewersTip.text: For a real authentic experience invite all of your friends around to help on brewday. Try splitting the batch up after primary fermentation and dry hopping at different rates to see which you prefer. You can also blend the different versions back together to see how that tastes, have fun with it!

description.text: Weve split our bets with Casino Rye Ale and doubled up on the malt front, with barley and rye on the grain bill.

brewersTip.text: We don't recommend roulette as a way to design beer. Spin the bottle is a much more sensible option. Make this beer with the freshest ingredients you can. Try to arrange brewday as close to delivery day as possible and throw 10 brewbucks on black 17 for us.

description.text: A dark and decadent beer brewed with coconut, vanilla, cacao.

brewersTip.text: Don't be shy with the roasted coconut, it's a delicate flavour compared to the rest of the beer, so go nuts! If it grows wild near you, go grab some Gorse and chuck it in too for a local natural boost to the coconut flavours.

description.text: Brewed in collaboration with our AGM-headlining band, Twin Atlantic, this US style pale features some of our favourite hops and is loaded with tropical fruit.

pairings: Jerk Chicken Kebabs with Mango Salsa

brewersTip.text: If you can't find an awesome Scottish band to collaborate with just pump up the volume on your stereo and have fun moshing whilst you're mashing in. Use ripe but fresh fruit and be prepared to lose extra volume to it. It'll be worth it.

twists.name: Mango and Pineapple added to FV after Primary fermentation

description.text: Hop Shot is a high-velocity hop hit. Our latest experiment in ice- distillation is a west coast IPA, subjected to Antarctic temperatures and concentrated by removing the ice that forms. The result is a 22% ABV hop grenade in a 110ml bottle.

pairings: Pork Burrito with a Habanero and Mango Chili Salsa

brewersTip.text: This level of alcohol can be achieved using a domestic freezer. Use a container with a tap close to the bottom so you can run the un-frozen, concentrated beer from under the ice on top. You may have to do this three or four times. The colder you freeze it the boozier it gets. Be careful to not dilute it too much when draining off the concentrated liquid after freezing so you dont dilute it too much

description.text: A 7.2% rye IPA loaded with grapefruit notes, pithy citrus, and huge resinous bitterness, with rye character. The Centennial and Columbus flavours are amplified by the spicy, dry rye.

brewersTip.text: Be prepared for a long sparge as the rye content is really high.

description.text: This brew is a pale ale fermented with Belgian yeast and spiced with coriander seed.

brewersTip.text: If you dry hop with extra Sorachi Ace you'll end up with an awesome extra hit of lemony zing but be warned, it'll go through a lot of interesting variations on the way, including coconut and even bubblegum! Give it time though and it'll land back at that lovely lemon zest that will compliment the coriander seeds perfectly.

description.text: A pale lager, with toasty biscuit malt balanced against a robust spicy bitterness.

brewersTip.text: To really nail this style you need to get the water right. Do a bit of research on water profiles and ask a local brewery if they can help you out with some water treatments.

description.text: A malt-forward Scotch ale with a complex but mellow mix of toast crust, caramel, hints of cocoa, and a light hop spiciness.

brewersTip.text: Pre-mix your malts to keep the conversion of starches to sugars even across the mash and give you a more uniform grain bed for lautering and sparging. This is a lot less labour intensive than manually stirring your speciality malts into your mash tun.

description.text: A pale lager, with toasty biscuit malt balances against a robust spicy bitterness.

brewersTip.text: Kellerbier translates to cellar beer, if you dont have a cellar just make sure to keep the fermentation temperature as close as possible to what you'd expect in a bavarian basement.

description.text: Intense spicy and citrusy notes backed up with a bitter edge and a warming but dry malt biscuit backbone. This beer comes into its own after cellaring cool for a few weeks.

brewersTip.text: Brew twice as much Belgian Tripel as you were planning on ageing - it's awesome on its own too!

description.text: A vermont style IPA, with low background bitterness, loaded with intense juicy fruit character.

brewersTip.text: Add the dry hops in separate muslin bags to increase surface area contact and reduce the amount of hop matter in the beer after dry hopping without reducing the characteristic hazy look of the beer.

description.text: This one-off brew is packed with all the decadent flavours and textures associated with Imperial Stouts. This can features exclusive artwork by The Red Dress.

brewersTip.text: Surface area contact is key in dry additions. Make sure your coffee and cacao nibs are weighed down with something and spread them out between multiple muslin bags if you can. This is not an exact science so taste as you go and swap out for fresh coffee and/or cacao if you haven't gotten the flavour you want after five days or so. You will not have this problem with the vanilla.

description.text: In 2006 James and Martin hijacked a beer dinner run by Michael Jackson, the acclaimed beer and whisky writer, and convinced him to taste one of their home brews. This was a defining moment in BrewDog prehistory, and that beer was the first incarnation of the ubiquitous Paradox. Aged in a variety of casks over the years, Paradox is dark, decadent and encapsulating. Can be enjoyed fresh; phenomenal when aged.

brewersTip.text: The beauty of this beer is in how brilliantly it lends itself to infusing or ageing. Experiment with different additions when the beer is ageing, taste it regularly to gauge its progress, and make sure you package it at its peak.

tips: Age this beer in Rye Whisky Casks

description.text: Tropic Thunder is the winner of the first ever # HomeBrewDog competition; the brainchild of Tom Doyle, this beer was the highest rated of the 307 beers that were tasted. A full-bodied and complex stout loaded with chocolate, mocha and roasty flavours, finishing with a vibrant burst of orange.

brewersTip.text: If you are feeling adventurous, and havent guzzled your whole batch upon first tasting it, try mulling this like you would a wine or cider. Cinnamon and clove will really lend themselves to the flavour of Tropic Thunder and mulled beer is definitely cooler than the usual offerings at a winter gathering.

description.text: BrewDog vs Cloudwater is a 6.8% Vermont-style India Pale Ale, hopped with Mosaic in the whirlpool only. Without any big- hitting additions of hops in the boil, we carried the flavour by heavily dry-hopping the brew with Citra and Mosaic. We also used oats in the recipe to deliver the trademark smooth mouthfeel  and made it truly authentic by propagating a one-off culture of Vermont yeast, specifically for the brew.

pairings: Baked Peaches with Citrus Fruit Reduction

brewersTip.text: Skip the arrageenan (Irish Moss), all haze is good haze in this beer.

description.text: An utterly indulgent, smooth as hell Stout. With opulent flavours of chocolate milkshake, roasty espresso coffee, and mellow vanilla, this beer has a full-bodied and creamy mouthfeel.

brewersTip.text: *Not a suitable replacement for an actual breakfast. Nitroing at home is, well, not impossible but unlikely. Luckily this beer tastes great when lightly carbonated too! Be prepared for a slow runoff and dont skimp on the cacao!

description.text: A second trial of our previous Small Batch Vermont IPA using a different yeast strain. A vermont style IPA, with low background bitterness, loaded with intense juicy fruit characters.

brewersTip.text: DONT add flour. This tip has been floating around for the style and its bad advice. Any and all murk should accompany something that enhances the beer. This little juice-box is dry hopped at a rate of 10g per litre. Wonder what would happen if you doubled that...

description.text: A bitter pils-style lager which is packed with aromas of citrus and a dry, refreshing biscuit malt backbone. Light floral notes add to the complexity.

pairings: Goat's cheese salad with walnuts, radish and blood orange

brewersTip.text: After boiling your wort, chill the wort down quickly to avoid the compound DMS forming. DMS gives beer a tinned sweetcorn like aroma.

description.text: East Coast Crush is a Vermont style pale ale, packaged and served using our custom LIVE beer dispense. A session Vermont IPA, with low background bitterness, loaded with intense juicy mango, pineapple, peach and pine.

brewersTip.text: Vermont Yeast, whilst desirable for this style of beer, is not absolutely necessary. The murk of a NEIPA can be achieved by malt selection and your process.

description.text: A one-off beer which combines the sweet and juicy flavour of stonefruit with tropical hop aromas. This can features exclusive artwork by Tracie Ching.

brewersTip.text: Adding the fruit at the end of the boil effectively pasteurises it. If you plan to add fruit after primary fermentation, buy aseptic puree or have a plan to pasteurise it before adding it.

description.text: Brewed to a concept voted on at Craft Beer Rising, this one-off beer is an experimental brew which emulates the flavour of lemon meringue pie.

brewersTip.text: Dextrin Malt adds sugars to your wort that the yeast are unable to ferment. If you want a sweetness remaining in your beer, add a little of this but not too much!!!

description.text: An imperial stout brewed with cacao and coffee, AB22 has spent two years in darkness, drawing complex and indulgent flavours from the Speyside whisky casks in which it resided.

brewersTip.text: Soak American oak (medium toasted) chips in your favourite Speyside tipple overnight and add them after primary fermentation.

twists.name: American Oak Chips Medium Toast soaked in Speyside whisky

description.text: A Vermont style IPA, with low background bitterness, loaded with juicy fruit character. Pine, stonefruit, mango, light resin and hints of lime peel - this juicy IPA is low in bitterness, full-bodied and smooth, enhancing the soft ripe fruit flavours.

brewersTip.text: This beer is supposed to be very cloudy. Dont be shy to get a good bit of the hot break into the fermenter.

description.text: An amplified version of a style we first brewed with Weihenstephan. A full-on deluge of spice and citrus, the new world hops bring spiced orange, lemon peel and fresh grassy and floral notes while the weizen base adds pepper, clove and banana.

brewersTip.text: A German style wheat beer that is mostly defined by its yeast character. Yeast strain has a massive influence on the final perception of the beer.

description.text: Our Equity Punk gypsy brewery - Beatnik Brewing Collective - voted for this recipe as their 2017 annual brew. A blonde stout brewed to export strength, the stout character comes from extra ingredients instead of dark malts.

brewersTip.text: An oxymoron of a beer. The cocoa nibs are vital in providing that stout like flavour without the associated colour.

description.text: A cream ale, brewed with raspberry and milk sugars, balancing sweet and tart summer berry with soft bitterness and a full bodied smooth mouthfeel.

pairings: Feta and tomato salad with balsamic dressing

brewersTip.text: Add heather honey to your boil to make this beer even better!!!

description.text: A pilot kit Small Batch, experimenting with weizen yeast, honey and spelt.

brewersTip.text: Spelt malt can slow your run off, similar to Rye. Take your time or add some extra malt to compensate for lower efficiency.

description.text: Our Prototype Challenge sees us pit three new trial beers against each other. This Double IPA is packed with a blend of our favourite American hops and has a huge dry- hop aroma.

pairings: Hot wings and blue cheese dip
Sticky toffee pudding and salted caramel ice cream

brewersTip.text: The hopping rate should leave a light residual haze in your beer after maturation. Dont worry, this comes from the hop compounds, haze is taste.

description.text: Our Prototype Challenge sees us pit three new trial beers against each other. This Black Rye IPA combines two spins on an American IPA, in the left-right jab combo of extra ingredients.

brewersTip.text: If you want the colour but less of the flavour of the dark malts, try substituting the Carafa Special III for a dehusked version of Carafa.

description.text: A citrus-infused gose - a traditional German sour wheat beer brewed with salt, in this case with the addition of kaffir lime leaf and lemon peel.

brewersTip.text: Play around with the citrus flavour by using differing amounts of lemon peel, orange peel, grapefruit peel, lime peel or kaffir lime leaves.

description.text: A classic German weissbeir with aromas of banana and clove, layered with New World hop aromas of orange.

brewersTip.text: If you want more phenolic (Banana & Spice) flavours, ferment at a higher temperature. If you want more fruit esters, keep the fermentation lower and under control.

description.text: This Blonde Ale is a new recipe and uses a new yeast - so it is a true Prototype. Originally lined up as part of the 2017 Prototype Challenge it was released shortly afterwards. but hey, these things happen.

brewersTip.text: This yeast strain produces a marked sulphurous note in the beer. If thats not your thing, dont Burtonise your mash and see the difference!

description.text: Our Abstrakt series showcases one- off beers, brewed or blended to the peak of our abilities. Each release is unique and never to be repeated.

pairings: Cherry chocolate cake with chocolate whipped mousse

brewersTip.text: Never put honey into your beer without pasteurising it. It is full of wild yeasts that are waiting to spoil your hard work.

twists.name: American Oak Chips Medium Toast soaked in Bourbon

description.text: Our Q4 Seasonal is a red rye IPA. This twist on an American IPA involves a more complex malt base, with the careful addition of rye - a grain known for its trickiness when brewing with anything above a tiny percentage.

pairings: Barbeque and mustard beef on rye bread

brewersTip.text: Rye can cause run off problems. Try to reach a temperature of 78 degrees Celsius if possible, and sparge at the same temperature.

description.text: In protest against the potential withdrawal of the USA from the Paris agreement, we brewed a saison (which ferments at high temperatures) with melted ice caps (glacier water) and cloudberries (an Arctic berry).

pairings: Oysters with a chilli and dill sauce

brewersTip.text: So your homebrew shop of choice may not stock all the ingredients here! You can buy cloudberry jam and add that instead. The pectin in the jam is not ideal and will form a haze but that can be forgiven in a saison.

description.text: Indulgent, complex, and endlessly rewarding; packed with flavours of toffee, coconut, red berry, burnt sugar, marzipan, orange, cherry - American oak adds structure and depth to this chewy and warming barley wine brewed with rye and aged in rye whiskey cask.

pairings: Cherry chocolate cake with chocolate whipped mousse

brewersTip.text: Be careful with brown malt. If you put too much in, it can very easily turn a fantastic tasting beer into a beer that tastes like someone has poured a pint into an ash tray, swirled it around and put it back into your pint.

twists.name: American Oak Chips Heavy Toast soaked in Bourbon

description.text: After the success of the first version of Sidewalk Shark (a BrewDog bar exclusive), we decided to brew a second version, this time infused with tropical flavours of pineapple, coconut and lime.

pairings: Baked Tilapia with lemon and cream sauce

brewersTip.text: Be careful with your salt additions. A very light saltiness aids the refreshing character. It should not overpower or drive you to seek another different beer to refresh your palate.

description.text: Our latest concept beer, AB:24 is a huge Baltic Porter, brewed with coffee and muscovado sugar.

pairings: Espresso brownies with burnt sugar ice cream

brewersTip.text: Do not substitute the muscovado sugar with white sugar. It lacks the molasses (black treacle) component that comes from only being partially refined.

description.text: Brewed exclusively for the German market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by Germany.

brewersTip.text: Morello Cherries are the go to cherry variety for this beer (and Krieks), the sour compliments the residual sweetness of the malt. Works well if you reduce your IBU to the 20 to 30 range too.

description.text: Brewed exclusively for the Finnish market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by Finland.

pairings: Steamed cod with ginger and spring onions

brewersTip.text: Instead of adding the blueberry juice in the kettle. Add fresh blueberries to your secondary fermenter, pitch The Yeast Bay's Melange Sour Blend and wait for 1 year.

description.text: Brewed exclusively for the Norwegian market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by Norway.

brewersTip.text: Strawberry is a very delicate flavour, so dont shy away with putting a lot more in when you dry hop.

description.text: Brewed exclusively for the French market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by France.

brewersTip.text: Save yourself a lot of hassle and buy the blackcurrant as a concentrate or cordial. Ribena time!

description.text: Brewed exclusively for the Swedish market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by Sweden.

brewersTip.text: Add the lingonberry juice either to the end of the boil or to the fermenter, depending on whether the juice has been pasteurised.

description.text: Brewed exclusively for the Dutch market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by the Netherlands

brewersTip.text: The Seville Orange is a bitter orange, so adjust your bittering hop addition down to account for the fact that there will be a contribution from them.

description.text: Brewed exclusively for the Irish market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by Ireland.

brewersTip.text: Save yourself a lot of hassle and buy the Elderflower as a concentrate or cordial. Collecting elderberries ranks low on the FPES (fruit picking enjoyment scale), can't imagine the flower picking is much better.

description.text: Brewed exclusively for the Italian market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavours inspired by Italy.

brewersTip.text: Keep an eye on your pH as you are adding your lemon juice. Yeast can tolerate low pH conditions but the length of fermentation may take longer than normal.

description.text: Brewed exclusively for the Spanish market, this Hello My Name brew features a twist of flavour inspired by Spain.

brewersTip.text: Using the mandarin in the mash means you can also throw in the peel to extract the essential oils from it. The pith can be quite bitter if it makes it into the boil.

recipes.name: I WANNA BE YOUR DOG
tags: OMNIPOLLO X BREWDOG - BARREL AGED IMPERIAL STOUT

description.text: A collaboration with Omnipollo, known for their uncanny ability to repilcate dessert avours in indulgent beers. This caramel and pecan avoured imperial stout has been barrel aged for almost a year in whisky casks, to add an extra level of depth to the pecan mud pie concept.

brewersTip.text: Dont be too quick to rack the beer off the yeast once your final gravity is reached. The stressed yeast will be absorbing a number of undesirable fermentation by-products such as acetaldehyde and diacetyl. Give them a minimum of 10 days at fermentation temperature to do this before cooling it down.

twists.name: American Oak Chips Medium Toast soaked in Speyside Whisky
American Oak Chips Heavy Toast soaked in Speyside Whisky

description.text: Our first single-hop Vermont IPA; all the flavour in this beer comes from a combination of Citra's naturally complex flavour profile, the yeast-produced esters, and the biotransformation of the hop oils by its contact with the yeast.

brewersTip.text: Pectin powder can easily be sourced and is an easy alternative for a homebrewer to produce murky beer if you dont have access to a low flocculating yeast.

description.text: This one-off brew showcases the flavours of a Mexican spiced hot chocolate, infused with an imperial stout.

brewersTip.text: Add virgin white oak chips soaked in a Reposado Tequila to give it a "South of the Wall" kick.

description.text: Off-Duty Alien is a citrus IPA, brewed with blood orange and grapefruit to enhance the citurs characteristics of the hops.

brewersTip.text: Adding the orange and grapefruit peels to the mash gently extracts the essential oils from the peel but leaves the bitter pith behind in the spent grain.

description.text: A Vermont IPA with fruit and milk sugars added - recreating fruity milkshake character in an IPA.

pairings: Thai sweet potato and carrot soup

brewersTip.text: If you use mango pulp, extend the time that you whirlpool to let it settle out. Trying to clean mango pulp out of your heat exchanger or cooling coil is not a fun ending to a brewday.

description.text: An exclusive barrel-aged blend, brought together to reward investors on Equity for Punks USA; two imperial stouts aged in grain whisky barrels for over a year.

brewersTip.text: The lactose kettle addition is unfermentable by yeast. Target a pre-boil OG of between 90 and 100, then use the lactose to increase it to the target OG.

description.text: A draft-only kettle-soured raspberry ale, brewed to just 0.5% ABV, using our knowledge from brewing both Blitz and Nanny State. Aromas of fresh raspberry juice, soft red berries, and a blast of lemon zest, with a juicy palate encompassing zingy acidity and the smooth velvety note of oats, rounding out this low-ABV juicebox.

pairings: Walnut and goat's cheese salad with pomegranate dressing

brewersTip.text: If you dont need it to be low ABV, try tripling the amount of malt to get more body. Experiment with different sources for lactic acid bacteria, like unpasteurised yogurt or sour dough.

description.text: A non-dry-hopped pale ale, using new hopping technqiues and in- depth fermentation know-how.

brewersTip.text: This beer is charactised by the subtle aromas derived from yeast. Ensure you have fresh healthy yeast and good temperature control to replicate these flavours.

description.text: A BrewDog bar exclusive draft lager, brewed with Weihenstephan's lager yeast, and dry-hopped with the contemporary German variety Saphir; this lager has been lightly centrifuged and packaged at just under 28 days in tank.

brewersTip.text: Before dry hopping, if you aren't happy with the "green" beer, drink it (or dump it) and make a new one to avoid wasting your premium hops on something flawed.

description.text: A draft-only BrewDog bar exclusive; we have experimented with ageing our Vermount IPA for a short time in bourbon and rye barrels, both known for imparting flavour quickly compared to other types of barrel.

brewersTip.text: Avoid any oxygen uptake! It will oxidise the delicate hop flavours during the ageing period. Purge your barrel / ageing vessel with CO2 and seal it airtight.

twists.name: American Oak chip medium toast, soaked in Bourbon

description.text: A draft-only BrewDog bar exclusive; we have experimented with ageing our Vermont IPA for a short time in bourbon and rye barrels, both known for imparting flavour quickly compared to other types of barrel.

pairings: Orange and carrot cake with orange cream cheese icing

brewersTip.text: Avoid any oxygen uptake! It will oxidise the delicate hop flavours during the ageing period. Purge your barrel / ageing vessel with CO2 and seal it airtight.

twists.name: American oak chips medium toast soaked in Rye Whisky

description.text: A draft-only exclusive beer for International markets as part of the DogDealers programme. Karma Cloud is a tropical IPA, designed to cram as much fruit flavour in as possible using only hops to recreate those flavours.

pairings: Roasted pork loin with tropical fruit

brewersTip.text: Using the latest year's hops is a must. Leave the beer conditioning on the hops for a maximum of 5 days, otherwise there is a risk of a green vegetal like character being extracted.

description.text: A big, dank, double IPA, sitting in the 8-9% ABV bracket, in our Amplified range - filling a gap that has been sitting empty since Hardcore IPA departed. A new beer developed by our Head of Production Jason Pond; the first brew he came up with since joining became an instant hit.

brewersTip.text: This beer is very hop centric. Use the youngest hops that are available and store them in a freezer. This will help slow the degradation of desirable hop compounds.

description.text: A super-smooth, full-bodied chewy- as-hell barley wine. Our latest concept brew spent 6 months drawing flavour from bourbon barrels.

pairings: Coarse pork pate with fresh crusty bread
Beef burger topped with red onions and wasabi

brewersTip.text: Waxing the bottle/cap helps to exclude oxygen ingress through the cap if you are looking to cellar the beer for a long time.

description.text: Our first 2018 Wildcard brew, Kamikaze Knitting Club is a one- off brew. A maple stout, Kamikaze combines dark malts with a classic Canadian export, adding to the warming malty and smokey character.

brewersTip.text: Try experimenting with fenugreek seeds which give off a maple syrup like flavour.

recipes.name: VERY BIG MOOSE (BREWDOG VS FIERCE BEER)

description.text: A rebrew of the Fierce Beer & Flagship bar Collabfest 2017 winning beer, Very Big Moose is being scaled up to our Ellon brewhouse.

pairings: Rich vanilla ice cream. Neat (or make a float)
Roast venison with a chocolate sauce
The biggest darkest chocolate cake you can find

brewersTip.text: Its probably best to parti-gyle this beer as this will have a  run off time of 6 hours+!!! Set up the mash and see what is collected overnight, then add more hot water to do your second mash and make a low (3%) beer from your residual extract.

description.text: Our longest running beer series, Paradox sees us ageing an Imperial Stout in different types of cask. This one showcases grain whisky.

pairings: Roast beef with a herb and malt crust

brewersTip.text: Brew this as part of a parti gyle mash, making this beer from your first runnings. It will take a long time to run off and be prepared to add dextrose to reach your target OG.

tips: Age this beer in Rye Whisky Casks

description.text: Winner of the 2017 Prototype Challenge, ClockWork Tangerine is a session strength IPA, infused with tangerine, and appears as our new Q2 Seasonal, replacing Hop Fiction.

pairings: Light and uffy tangerine sponge cake
Fresh green salad with avocados and pomegranate seeds

brewersTip.text: Try your own fruit series with this beer. Grapefruit, Passionfruit, Rapberries or Morello Cherries would be great.

description.text: Welcome aboard our experimental range of tuned IPAs. Buckle up for an explosive sensory bombardment. Tropical fruit and resinous pine are primed. The first wave of pineapple, melon and mango quickly accelerate into a afterburner of candied citrus fruit and sweet caramel. Sonic Boom - IPA turning at the speed of sound.

brewersTip.text: This IPA features German hops in the dry hop. Why not try a Slovenian only version using: Dana, Bobek, Aurora & Cascade.

description.text: Dog G is a benchmark in liquid form; our 11th anniversary beer. A 17% imperial stout brewed with a compelling mix of dark malts, chillies, cacao and coffee - to  make it a true milestone we then decided to age Dog G in rye whiskey barrels.

brewersTip.text: Age this beer!!! Often it will pick up new incredible flavours after an extended cellaring. Think 2 years plus

twists.name: 5g Habanero and 3g lemon drop chili in FV

description.text: One of a series of collaborations with European craft breweries, aimed at promoting engagement and market growth. With Norwegian craft brewers Amundsen, we are creating a mash-up of two existing beers, resulting in a coffee, chocolate and marshmallow Russian Imperial Stout.

brewersTip.text: If your mash run off takes a long time, increase the temperature of your sparge water to keep the mash bed warm and permeable.

description.text: One of a series of collaborations with European craft breweries, aimed at promoting engagement and market growth. Our Swedish collaboration with Brewski is a mango IPA.

pairings: Pho soup with light rice noodles

brewersTip.text: Add the mango puree towards the end of primary fermentation, about 10 SG points above your FG. Allow it to reach FG and have a diacetyl rest before dry hopping it.

description.text: One of a series of collaborations with European craft breweries, aimed at promoting engagement and market growth. Our Austrian collaboration is with Bevog, and incorporates plum into a Baltic porter.

brewersTip.text: Double Roasted Crystal is used when the astringency and bitterness inherent to roast malts is not desired. This means that it can be used at a higher rate in the grist to add complex caramel and dried fruit notes with a beautiful red-brown hue.

description.text: One of a series of collaborations with European craft breweries, aimed at promoting engagement and market growth. Our German collaboration is with BRLO, and the beer is  a dry- hopped Maibock; a new world take on a strong pale lager.

brewersTip.text: Traditional German brewing is awesome and deserving of respect. If you brew this during spring time, call it a Maibock, any other time of the year and it should be called an Helles Bock.

recipes.name: AL ADJORE! BREWDOG VS LA PIRATA

description.text: One of a series of collaborations with European craft breweries, aimed at promoting engagement and market growth. Our collab with Spanish brewes La Pirata features a barley wine, inspired by Muscatel.

brewersTip.text: Sanitise the oak chips before adding them to the fermenter. Vodka is ideal as its a neutral spirit and can be drained off. If you dont want to affect the ABV, try steaming them.

description.text: One of a series of collaborations with European craft breweries, aimed at promoting engagement and market growth. This India pale lager has been brewed with Dutch brewers Oedipus.

pairings: Spicy jalapeño and seared steak fajitas

brewersTip.text: Acidulated malt was first produced to circumvent the Reinheitsgebot in Germany where they could not acidify their brewing water. A weak organic acid such as lactic acid can be used in its place.

recipes.name: GRANO GIUSTO BREWDOG VS BIRRIFICIO ITALIANO

description.text: One of a series of collaborations with European craft breweries, aimed at promoting engagement and market growth. Our Italian collaboration is with Birrificiano Italiano, and the beer is a dark lager brewed with a unique dark malt from an Italian micro-maltster.

brewersTip.text: Grano dei Miracoli is aunique ancient grain andshouldn'tbesubstituted, this beer is focused on what thisingredient offers when paired withmodern malts.

description.text: A new 7.4% ABV East Coast IPA, King of Eights is one of the core Fanzine beers, and will feature evolving editions as part of our new subscription model.

brewersTip.text: Pectin powder can easily be sourced and is an easy alternative for a homebrewer to produce murky beer if you dont have access to a low flocculating yeast.

description.text: A new 4.7% ABV American pale ale, Jinx Pale Ale is one of the core Fanzine beers, and will feature evolving editions as part of our new subscription model.

brewersTip.text: Rack this into a corny keg, cool it down and carbonate it with 10 PSI of top pressure for 10 days. Should be super drinkable.

description.text: A new 6.9% ABV West Coast IPA, Jet Trash is one of the core Fanzine beers, and will feature evolving editions as part of our new subscription model.

brewersTip.text: Split this batch and try fermenting the other half with WLP008 East Coast Ale, dry hop whilst primary fermentation is going and have an East Coast IPA to compare with.

description.text: A new 5% ABV Vienna Lager, that features in Fanzine, our new subscription model.

brewersTip.text: Instead of using Pilsner, try to substitute this out for more Vienna malt. This is more traditional but you should calculate your diastatic power for your new mash. Ideally it should be a minimum of 30 to 50 Lintner.

description.text: A new 5.6% Dortmunder Lager, that featues in Fanzine, our new subscription model.

brewersTip.text: Make sure you burtonise your water as Dortmund's water contains a fairly high amount of sulphates. Carbonate this to approximately 2.6 volumes

description.text: A new 5% Pilsner, that feaures in Fanzine, our new subscription model.

brewersTip.text: Saphir hops are not widespread at the moment if you cannot get hold of any, a good batch of Mittlefruh is a fair substitute.

recipes.name: THE EMPERORS BLUE CLOTHES (BD VS PEOPLE LIKE US)

description.text: Brewed in collaboration with People Like Us, this wheat beer sits just between a weissbier and a dunkelweisse, and is loaded with blueberry juice.

brewersTip.text: Adding juices adds both sweetness and acidity to your beer - although these beers have been designed to have the right balance, play around with the quantity of the juice to add different levels of acidity and flavour of your beer.

description.text: A new 4.6% ABV tart pale ale. Zephyr is one of the core Fanzine beers, and will feature evolving editions as part of our new subscription model.

brewersTip.text: Lactic acid, malic acid and citric acid all give different perception of acidity and flavour at the same concentration. Play around with them in water to understand their interaction and optimise your own recipe.

description.text: A trial brew, testing our new Zephyr concept - a Berliner-style pale, infused with tangerine.

brewersTip.text: Adding juices adds both sweetness and acidity to your beer - although these beers have been designed to have the right balance, play around with the quantity of the juice to add different levels of acidity and flavour of your beer.

description.text: A new wave session IPA. We've cranked up the wheat and oats and turned down the ABV, creating a juicy equilibrium. This is a beer that has all of the taste of a New England IPA, but allows a more sessionable delivery.

brewersTip.text: Don't cool the beer too cold after fermentation or you will loose the haze, 3°C should do.

description.text: Our Red Rye IPA, Albino Squid Assassin, barrel aged in rye  a rebrew of one of our most requested barrel-aged beers.

brewersTip.text: Allow the fermentation to go as far as possible. Soak oak chips in whisky to get the barrel aged characteristic.

description.text: A 4.6% tart pale ale. It has a twist of tartness up-front, with juicy sour fruit notes dominating the palate.

brewersTip.text: Adding juices adds both sweetness and acidity to your beer - although these beers have been designed to have the right balance, play around with the quantity of the juice to add different levels of acidity and flavour of your beer.

description.text: An 8% East Coast IPA with eight hops, to celebrate the eight breweries featuring at our Punk AGM 2018; Cloudwater, Deya, Magic Rock, Stillwater, The Bruery, Northern Monk, Seventh Son, and of course, us.

brewersTip.text: Add both sweet and bitter orange peels into the mash, play around with the ratio and quantity to find the right balance for your taste.

description.text: A new 10% ABV Imperial Stout. It is one of the core Fanzine beers, and will feature evolving editions as part of our subscription model.

brewersTip.text: Condition for up to a month at 1°C for best results.

description.text: A trial brew, testing our new Zephyr concept - a Berliner-style pale, infused with lemon.

brewersTip.text: Adding juices adds both sweetness and acidity to your beer - although these beers have been designed to have the right balance, play around with the quantity of the juice to add different levels of acidity and flavour of your beer.
