description.text: A scaled up rebrew of our recent milkshake IPA. A hazy New England DIPA, loaded with mango and peach resulting in an explosive aroma and a sweet full-bodied fruit shake flavour.

brewersTip.text: Don't cool the beer too cold after fermentation or you will loose the haze, 3°C should do.

description.text: A Fanzine release, evolving from Nebula and featuring espresso coffee.

brewersTip.text: Add ground coffee in muslin bags directly at conditioning.

description.text: A trial brew, testing out our new Zephyr concept - a Berliner-style pale, infused with blueberry.

brewersTip.text: Adding juices adds both sweetness and acidity to your beer - although these beers have been designed to have the right balance, play around with the quantity of the juice to add different levels of acidity and flavour of your beer.

description.text: A Fanzine released American Double IPA, created as a one-off for our subscription club.

brewersTip.text: Allow for 36 to 48 hours for the initial dry hop before adding the second dry hop addition.

description.text: One of a series of collaborations with European craft breweries, aimed at promoting engagement and market growth. With French craft brewers Brasserie La Goutte D'or, we are brewing a stout with South African influences.

brewersTip.text: Load rooibos tea into the hot wort in a using a tea bag or muslin cloth at flame out.

description.text: A one-off Fanzine Double IPA, amplifying the Clockwork Tangerine concept.

brewersTip.text: Add both sweet and bitter orange peels into the mash, play around with the ratio and quantity to find the right balance for your taste.

description.text: A New England style IPA, double dry hopped and over-indexing on the incredible flavours of citra. Huge aromas of stonefruit and ripe tropical fruit, followed by a smooth, juicy and full-bodied palate and a soft bitterness.

brewersTip.text: The experimental hop HBC 438 used for this brew is now named Sabro. This will bring a huge pineapple aroma to the finished beer.

description.text: An experimental IPA. Replacing our single hop series, this series of IPAs will allow our brew team to experiment with hops, with the base beer unchanging from release to release. New and experimental varieties, new hopping techniques, or whatever they want to do to evolve the beer each time round.

brewersTip.text: We've experimented with this beer so you should too! Try swapping some hops out for others, have fun with it.

description.text: A New England IPA brewed with raspberry, oats and milk sugar.

brewersTip.text: Add the raspberry puree at flame out, the sugars will ferment out and this is fine. The residual sweetness comes from the milk sugars (lactose).

description.text: Our latest session sour, this time based on Piña Colada.

brewersTip.text: Used toasted coconut in the mash and steep in the cold conditioning phase to emphasis the Piña Colada smoothness.

description.text: A Fanzine release, alongside the international draft exclusive. Vinyl Vigilante is a Coffee Milk Stout, taking the coffee avours already present in dark ales and enhancing them.

brewersTip.text: Use freshly ground coffee for the best aromatic hit. Consider the addition of cold brew coffee into the secondary.  This will give a big coffee flavour but not impart any of the astringent bitterness of over extracted coffee, just be careful not to add too much and dilute the beer.

description.text: A double dry hopped edition of our 6.9% ABV west coast IPA, Jet Trash. Its the second version of one of our core Fanzine beers, and will continue to feature evolving editions.

pairings: Carrot Cake with Orange, Pistachio and Pomegranate

brewersTip.text: Allow for 36 to 48 hours for the initial dry hop before adding the second dry hop addition.

description.text: An aggressive black IPA with a spicy hint of rye. Intense flavours for the lovers of bitterness, balanced beautifully between malt and hops.

brewersTip.text: To boost the colour but less of the roasted flavour of the dark malts, try substituting the Carafa ® special III for a dehusked version of Carafa ® that delivers a smoother flavour.

description.text: A Fanzine release which has been dry hopped three consecutive times with three different hops. It's crammed with fresh tropical vibes from Citra, Comet and Mosaic.

brewersTip.text: Depending on the yeast strain and hops youre using, you can benet from the effect of biotransformation by dry hopping before the primary fermentation is nished. Some yeasts are capable of extracting extra avours from the hops. The earlier you dry hop in the fermentation process, the more avour is extracted from the hops through the process of biotransformation, however at the same time more avour also disappears again through the stripping effect of the generated CO2. A good balance is to add the hops just before primary fermentation is nished.

description.text: A double dry hopped edition of our recent milkshake IPAs, this fruited NEIPA combines peach, mango and milk sugar with low bitterness and extreme dry hopping rates.

brewersTip.text: Depending on the yeast strain and hops youre using, you can benet from the effect of biotransformation by dry hopping before the primary fermentation is nished. Some yeasts are capable of extracting extra avours from the hops. The earlier you dry hop in the fermentation process, the more avour is extracted from the hops through the process of biotransformation, however at the same time more avour also disappears again through the stripping effect of the generated CO . A good balance is to add the hops just before primary fermentation is nished. 2

description.text: A 14% ABV Russian Imperial Stout brewed as an EFP V referral reward. Aggressive and imposing, this massive stout is black as pitch and delivers huge and complex flavours.

brewersTip.text: A long mash rest is essential for complete attenuation.

description.text: The triumphant return of our democratic brewing concept; Mashtag sees us run a series of votes to determine each element of the beer. This year, at the publics request, we have brewed an American pale ale with hibiscus flower and yuzu.

brewersTip.text: Adding hibiscus at fermentation temp will allow for maximum flavour and colour extraction.

description.text: Our annual EFP-designed beatnik brew. The winning concept is a raspberry cheesecake inspired imperial stout.

brewersTip.text: When using fresh fruit, it is best to freeze it to both sanitise without chemicals or alcohol and to cause the cells within the fruit to burst allowing for maximum flavour extraction.

description.text: A 5% take on a New England IPA, for our Fanzine subscription club.

brewersTip.text: The key to NEIPA is a lot of hops at flame out for no longer than 15 minutes to extract flavour and aroma without adding any additional bitterness.

description.text: A Fanzine release, evolving from nebula and featuring espresso coffee and vanilla.

brewersTip.text: To create a full on coffee flavour without adding any astringency, make a strong cold brew.

description.text: An ode to the glory of hops. It brings massive fresh hop notes of pine dust, lemongrass, lemon peel and freshly cut grass, layered on dry biscuit malt,  a hint of alcohol warmth, and followed up with a sudden torrent of mango, lime, apricot, papaya, peach and more.

brewersTip.text: Be careful to use fresh hops for dry hopping.

description.text: An American pale ale brewed to celebrate the launch of our brand new TV network.

brewersTip.text: The key to this beer is aroma hops at flame out for no more than 15 minutes to achieve maximum flavour without any additional bitterness.

description.text: A session strength sour ale infused with grapefruit and tangerine. A straightforward, easy-going introduction to sour beer.

brewersTip.text: A low pH at fermentation is normal, usually under 4 pH.

description.text: A return of a BrewDog favourite, at a more sessionable strength. Hop Fiction is back, in a more exclusive capacity.

brewersTip.text: Be careful to use fresh hops for dry hopping.

description.text: A dry hopped imperial lager, brewed for Dog Dealers and Fanzine. It's a big, toasty lager, packed with pilsner malt character, layered with a soft and yielding Sauvignon-like dry hop flavour.

pairings: Black Bean Tostadas with Avocado Salsa

brewersTip.text: Condition the beer for at least 15 days at 1°C.

description.text: A Fanzine exclusive American pale ale, aggressively dry hopped with a range of new world varieties.

brewersTip.text: Depending on the yeast strain and hops youre using, you can benet from the effect of biotransformation by dry hopping before the primary fermentation is nished. Some yeasts are capable of extracting extra avours from the hops. The earlier you dry hop in the fermentation process, the more avour is extracted from the hops through the process of biotransformation, however at the same time more avour also disappears again through the stripping effect of the generated CO2. A good balance is to add the hops just before primary fermentation is nished.

description.text: The last planned twist on King of Eights for the foreseeable future, this version showcases the flavours of new German hops in a lightly hazy New England IPA.

brewersTip.text: Don't cool the beer too cold after fermentation or you will loose the haze, 3°C should do.

description.text: A punchy IPA with a hefty hop bill. A deft touch of caramel and toast runs alongside massive hoppy aromas of pine, mango, grapefruit and lychee. Finishing with just a hint of sweetness, this classically West Coast IPA is dry, aggressive, and puts big hop avours front and centre.

brewersTip.text: Be careful to use fresh hops for dry hopping.

description.text: A Fanzine imperial stout with additions of cherry and vanilla.

pairings: Godminster Vintage with Caramelised Cranberry Relish

brewersTip.text: When using berries, it is best to freeze them rst to sanitise the fruit and to burst the cells within the fruit for maximum avour extraction. They should also be added after primary fermentation, this will keep a lot more avour and aroma in the beer as the secondary fermentation won't be as mettlesome as the primary fermentation.

description.text: One of our longest running brews returned as a brand new take on a fruity kettle sour. Inspired by our old favourite Berliner Weisse Raspberry Blitz, and using our recent Raspberry Popsicle Parade as a testing ground, this is an alcohol free Berliner Weisse, jam-packed with fruit flavour.

pairings: Brie and Goats Cheese Topped Pizza

brewersTip.text: For extra body, add a little milk sugars (lactose) to the brew.

description.text: Experimental IPA Series. Replacing our single hop series, this series of IPAs will allow our brew team to experiment with hops, with the base beer unchanging from release to release. New and experimental varieties, new hopping techniques, or whatever they want to do to evolve the beer each time round.

brewersTip.text: Make sure your hops have been stored in an oxygen free environment, especially for the dry hops.

description.text: A pilsner that combines the light, crisp and clean lager profile provided by Weihenstephan's house yeast, with the vibrant citrus and stonefruit aromas associated with new German hop Saphir. This lager is easy-going but has subtle depths; toast, hints of spice and a zesty lime marmalade character.

brewersTip.text: Temperature control is extremely important for Lager, fermentation temperature around 10-12°C and a maturation period of 3-4 weeks at 1.5-2°C is ideal.

description.text: A full scale, tweaked version of a tiny batch tested out early in 2018.

brewersTip.text: Pectin is added to give some stable haziness in the beer.

description.text: A more traditional style of saison, with additions of rye, citrus peel and peppercorns.

brewersTip.text: When using spices it is best to add them at flame out for no more than 15 minutes, too long or at too high a heat can result in unwanted bitterness.

description.text: A west coast IPA, with old school US hops, squeezed for all theyre worth  this Fanzine edition sees us cram some of the longest standing US hops into a light and punchy IPA.

brewersTip.text: Be careful to use fresh hops for dry hopping.

description.text: Our first Brut IPA brewed in Ellon, for Fanzine. A bone dry, tropical, Sauvignon-like IPA, with a champagne-like body, exceptionally dry and effervescent.

brewersTip.text: Pay special attention to that initial low mash temperature in order to get the body right on the final beer.

description.text: A Fanzine West Coast IPA, heavily whirlpool and dry hopped, and with lower than normal kettle hopping.

brewersTip.text: Depending on the yeast strain and hops youre using, you can benet from the effect of biotransformation by dry hopping before the primary fermentation is nished. Some yeasts are capable of extracting extra avours from the hops. The earlier you dry hop in the fermentation process, the more avour is extracted from the hops through the process of biotransformation, however at the same time more avour also disappears again through the stripping effect of the generated CO . A good balance is to add the hops just before primary fermentation is nished. 2

description.text: A big Imperial Red Ale brewed for Fanzine, with a blend of pan-global hops providing a broad flavour profile, while a blend of crystal malts gives colour and depth of flavour.

brewersTip.text: Make sure to limit contact with air when transferring, these dark red beers are very sensitive to oxidation.

description.text: An Oktoberfest beer for our Fanzine and our bars.

brewersTip.text: Condition the beer for at least 15 days at 1°C.

description.text: A single hop IPA showcasing ahtanum, a hop that we use more than anyone else in the world. This single hop IPA is a USA style IPA .

pairings: Goats Cheese and Caramelised Onion Tart

brewersTip.text: Make sure and follow the WK dosing schedule, these single hop beers get their complexity by adding hops at different times.

description.text: An imperial stout that has been aged in oak barrels that contained Uncle Duke's, our category defying Bourbon/Scotch whisky.

brewersTip.text: If youre are lucky enough to own a barrel to age your beers in, be sure to take good care of it. Especially when barrels are empty, they need some TLC. When you dont have beer in the barrel always keep it full of water to prevent it drying out. Getting a dry barrel to stop leaking is very hard to impossible. Should you encounter microbiological problems, burning sulphur wicks in the barrel or keeping it filled up with a sulphite/citric acid solution can help.

description.text: A Fanzine release, this imperial red IPA is part of a Halloween inspired issue. Big rounded sweet character drawn from a range of malt varieties, while an apple-like character is hinted at through the fermentation profile.

brewersTip.text: The malt backbone of this brew would easily allow for creating a dank red ale by changing the hops for West Coast hops, columbus, chinook, cascade and centennial.

description.text: A black New England IPA , released as a Halloween inspired Fanzine issue.

brewersTip.text: This beer is supposed to be very cloudy. Dont be shy to get a good bit of the hot break into the fermenter.

description.text: A one-off experimental IPA for our bars.

brewersTip.text: Experiment with the quantities of the Yuzu and Coconut.

description.text: A West Coast IPA for our Fanzine subscription club, heavily whirlpooled and dry hopped.

brewersTip.text: Make sure your hops have been stored in an oxygen free environment, especially for the dry hops.

description.text: A one-off stout for our Fanzine subscription club. The addition of salt gives the profile of an oyster stout, without the addition of shellfish. The hint of salt enhances the sweetness of the specialty malts, but must be carefully balanced with the bitterness.

brewersTip.text: Add salt to taste - too much will totally ruin the balance of your beer.

description.text: A big and warming imperial stout, great any time of year but particularly suitable for the Christmas festive season.

brewersTip.text: A little chilli goes a long way!

description.text: An easy-going Vienna style lager, packed with complex yet subtle malt flavours, at sessionable strength. Available for the Festive period only.

brewersTip.text: Condition for up to a month at 1°C for best results.

description.text: A Scotch ale with avours reminiscent of both Dogma and 5AM Saint. This caramelly, rounded wee heavy brewed for Fanzine, is infused with salt, bringing out the toffee notes and adding a softly savoury counterpoint to a huge, decadent beer.

brewersTip.text: Crush the malt as close to brewing time as possible. The fresher the malt, the more intense caramel flavours will be released in the wort.

description.text: An exploration around lager style brewed for our Fanzine subscribers.

brewersTip.text: Wheat adds protein which is essential for haze forming compounds.

description.text: An opaque creamy dry hopped IPA brewed for Fanzine.

brewersTip.text: Don't cool the beer too cold after fermentation or you will loose the haze, 3°C should do.

description.text: A warm and balanced Imperial Stout aged in rye barrels.

brewersTip.text: Condition for up to a month at 1°C for best results.

description.text: A complex, very dark beer that has been aged in bourbon barrels, giving it warming aromas, and balancing the notes of cherries, prunes, raisins and forest fruits. The mouthfeel is syrupy, the avours are thick and sweet.

brewersTip.text: If you want to speed up the barrel ageing, try storing the barrel at warmer temperatures. Or even better uctuating temperatures from cold to warm. This will increase the contraction of the wood bres and speed up the release of its avours. The beer losses might increase though.

description.text: A very juicy New England IPA with amazing tropical and passionfruit aromas, brewed for Fanzine.

brewersTip.text: For maximum passionfruit flavour, scoop out the passion fruit, blend in a food processor then freeze in a sterile container to sanitise without chemicals or alcohol, defrost and add to the beer. Don't worry about seeds as they'll sink to the bottom.

description.text: A very comforting Imperial Milk Stout, brewed for Fanzine with marshmallows and cocoa nibs, to recreate the specific smores flavour  a famous campfire treat from the USA.

brewersTip.text: Put coffee beans and cocoa nibs in a cheese cloth and dip in wort like a tea bag. Do multiple small additions for short lengths of time  the longer you leave them in the more heavy oils will be extracted.

description.text: Black as a Samurai's robe and busier than Shibuya crossing. This inky stout is alive with flavour. An earthquake on the plate - Jasmine is off the Richter with sticky caramel, nuts and roasted barley in close pursuit. Mixed berries ride out this liquid tsunami to complement and balance the malted profile.

pairings: Baked Honey Glazed Ham with Dark Fruit Sauce
Herbal Roast Beef with Cranberry Jus

brewersTip.text: For this beer to be successful a few key points need to be followed. The rst is picking the correct yeast strain, one that is known to be able to have high alcohol tolerance. The second is that by starting the brew with all the sugar necessary to gain +12% beers subjects the yeast to high osmotic stress and will hinder fermentation, so it is best to start with wort just over 1.100. And nally once fermentation has decreased and moving approximately 1SG point per 24hrs, it is time to start adding dextrose to achieve target ABV.

description.text: A maple and coffee barley wine brewed for Fanzine January issue.

brewersTip.text: Add coffee after the boil to get more coffee flavour and less bitterness.

description.text: A session strength pale ale with a huge, rounded mouthfeel, on which the hopload is built, brewed for Fanzine January issue.

brewersTip.text: Add heather honey to your boil to give this brew even more of a porridgey feel!

description.text: A 9.5% Raspberry dry hopped NEDIPA, brewed for Fanzine January issue.

brewersTip.text: The best fruit juice to use will have the pectin removed.

description.text: A low ABV version of an American pale ale. Retaining the hop profile but dialling down the basic malts. The addition of wheat and oats adds structure to support the lower pale malt base. The hop levels are still in line with our pale and hoppy core beers.

pairings: Feta and Greens Salad with Citrus Dressing

brewersTip.text: In any low ABV fermentation after primary fermentation has finished if the beer smells or tastes like wort, allow it to condition on the yeast for an extra 24 - 48 hours. This can round the profile off well.

description.text: A collaboration beer created for the Malmö beer and whisky festival in March. When deciding how best to celebrate this opportunity, we agreed to collaborate with one of Malmö's own, Brygghuset Finn - an award winning brewery that works according to traditional craft methods combined with innovative engineering skills.

brewersTip.text: Don't cool the beer too cold after fermentation or you will loose the haze, 3°C should do.

description.text: Brewed to celebrate the world's first craft beer airline, this beer is best enjoyed at altitude. As pale and hazy yellow as a transatlantic sunrise. Floral, citrus and freshly cut grass aromas fill the cabin. Orange, lemon and white grapes disembark in rapid succession, all resting on a malted fuselage. Sit back, relax and enjoy the Flight Club.

brewersTip.text: Nothing harmful will happen if this beer is consumed at sea level.

description.text: Our latest Paradox embraces time like no other. Aged in Islay casks from islands that cling to the edge of Scotland it can trace a lineage back ten thousand years. Underground, out of sight, but never out of mind, peat lies recumbent until called upon. The intense, smoky peated whiskies of our home nation are unique and inspiring - and they now give their avour to our latest Paradox.

brewersTip.text: The intensity of peated whiskies varies from mild to hardcore. When you choose a barrel or wood chips try to find out which whisky was stored in it. Get a sample of that whisky, taste it (thats the best part) and decide if it will go well with the beer.

description.text: A collaboration beer brewed with Buxton Brewery. The second collaboration brew of the year!

pairings: Apple Crumble with a Madagascan Vanilla Ice Cream

brewersTip.text: Rye can cause run off problems. Try to reach a temperature of 78°C if possible, and sparge at the same temperature.

description.text: Dark forces are at work in this devilishly good Praline Porter. Toffee and chocolate unite and come a-knocking. Open up to layers of smooth roasty character, with notes of vanilla, mellow coffee and a subtle nuttiness. And a bittersweet cliff-hanger finale. Zombie Cake - Bittersweet, engaging and rewarding.

brewersTip.text: Add the honey close to the end of the whirlpool to ensure the aroma stays in the beer.

description.text: Dog H is our liquid milestone, brewed to celebrate our twelfth anniversary. So what else could we do but turn it up to that number?

brewersTip.text: For this beer to be successful a few key points need to be followed. The rst is picking the correct yeast strain, one that is known to be able to have high alcohol tolerance. The second is that by starting the brew with all the sugar necessary to gain +12% beers subjects the yeast to high osmotic stress and will hinder fermentation, so it is best to start with wort just over 1.100. And nally once fermentation has decreased and moving approximately 1SG point per 24hrs, it is time to start adding dextrose to achieve target ABV.

description.text: A sophisticated Brut. Pours vibrant pale yellowy-orange. Tropical fruit on the nose. Lemon citrus, white grapes and floral notes with a big juicy mango hit and a deft touch of spice. Delivered Sahara dry with champagne like effervescence.

brewersTip.text: Dextrose is used to reach a very high attenuation in order to get that dry feeling.

description.text: Slip anchor and set sail with this silky smooth porter. Toffee and chocolate on the nose. Delivering a rich and chewy decadent cargo. Melted caramel and dark chocolate layer onto a rich dark oaky hull.

brewersTip.text: Mash in at a higher temperature to leave more unfermentable sugars in the wort. This gives the beer a sweeter porter profile.

description.text: Part of our brewer built series, showcasing beers designed and chosen by our brewers. This beer was created and crafted by Patrick Robb.

brewersTip.text: This beer is meant to be hazy so no sweat!

description.text: Part of our brewer built series, showcasing beers designed and chosen by our brewers. This beer was created and crafted by Andrew Hamilton.

brewersTip.text: The key is to use toasted coconut, toasting it will help bring out the flavour and sanitize it. Spread the coconut on a baking sheet and place it in the oven until the coconut starts to turn golden brown at the ends. Then place it in a muslin bag and steep it in the cold conditioning phase until you get the desired flavour. A few days should do.

description.text: Part of our brewer built series, showcasing beers designed and chosen by our brewers. This beer was created and crafted by Pietro Maltinti.

brewersTip.text: Because you're using a new generation of German hops (which age very quickly), the key for having very intense, pleasant aroma is to use very fresh hops, or your result can be disappointing.

description.text: Cosmic Crush is Overworks year round available sour beer range focusing on single fruit additions. This one's cherry!

brewersTip.text: It is best to remove the stems and stones from the cherries to avoid spicy flavours, allowing the bright fruit character to shine through.

description.text: Cosmic Crush is Overworks year round available sour beer range focusing on single fruit additions. This one's quince!

pairings: Red Wine and Spice Poached Quince with Mascarpone
Goats Cheese Tart with caramelized Onions

brewersTip.text: Freezing and thawing the fruit before adding it to the beer will rupture the cell walls, enabling more of the fruit character to develop within the beer.

description.text: Cosmic Crush is Overworks year round available sour beer range focusing on single fruit additions. This one's peach!

pairings: Spinach, Walnut and Blue Cheese Salad
Moroccan Style Grilled Chicken and Cous Cous Salad

brewersTip.text: Removing the stones from the peaches will avoid any harsh flavours in your finished beer, but make sure to add the skin for flavour and colour.

description.text: Cosmic Crush is Overworks year round available sour beer range focusing on single fruit additions. This one's tropical!

brewersTip.text: The tropical fruits can produce a lot of sulphur. A pitch of fresh yeast for a healthy refermentation should help deal with this.

description.text: Cosmic Crush is Overworks year round available sour beer range focusing on single fruit additions. This one's raspberry!

pairings: Radicchio Salad with Beans, Walnuts and Figs

brewersTip.text: Don't be afraid to add more raspberries. The colour and flavour will both benefit. Pitching a little fresh yeast can help kick off refermentation after the fruit is added.

description.text: We are taking our absurd passion for hops and our new-found infatuation with funky, wild beer and combining the two in one glass.

pairings: Soft Crofter's Cheese and Oat Cakes

brewersTip.text: Rack the beer off the hops after around four days. This will help to avoid too much raw hop flavour in your finished beer.

description.text: Amplifying the earthy sweetness of carrots with brettanomyces fermentation. Sweet mango helps to balance the funky dryness, and ginger ties the two elements together.

brewersTip.text: Experiment with the dosage of the ginger tea to ensure you don't overpower the more delicate avours of carrot and mango.

description.text: Taking the classic pairing of blueberry and lavender amplifying the pairing by incorporating them in to a Scottish sour ale.

brewersTip.text: Once you have made your lavender infusion, experiment with dosing rates to suit your beer.

description.text: Fragrant combination of gooseberries and elderflower amplified by incorporating in to a Scottish sour ale.

pairings: Grilled Mackerel with Soy and Ginger Glaze

brewersTip.text: Ensure you squash down your gooseberries to allow them to release their sugars for a good additional fermentation.

description.text: Taking the classic pairing of plums and vanilla and amplifying the pairing by incorporating them in to a Scottish sour ale.

brewersTip.text: Experiment with hot and cold extraction of the vanilla to see which method suits your vanilla pods best. A combination of both might yield the best results.
